data.text: @Brocialismo @ichudov In that case perhaps it could be called something like "SARS spike syndrome" to differentiate it from someone complaining of Long Covid who might only have lost their sense of smell. Anyway enough of this I'm sure you know where I'm coming from and we all have things to do 👍

@Brocialismo Yes but my point was different. Let's say you see a Doctor with a problem caused by Covid, he wont say "here's your Long Covid medicine", (because it's meaningless, LC isn't a specific thing) but he might say, "you have blood clots caused by Covid here's your blood clot medicine"

@prwright55 @ichudov Anyway, one of the main theories surrounding the question of ‘Long Covid’ posits that the persistence of various anomalous/chronic symptoms are a function of the body’s inability to fully shed the spike pathogen (certain parts of the body functions as spike ‘reservoirs’).

@prwright55 @ichudov It’s a novel/poorly understood virus that lacks both short term and longterm Tx protocols. (And don’t expect the Western medical establishment to even begin to direct any serious attention to Long Covid until some breakthrough is finally made in controlling the pandemic).

@prwright55 @ichudov Because the range of symptoms often don’t lend themselves to a diagnosis of a conventional disease—e.g. diabetes, cancer, etc. (though I can assure you that many thousands of PTs are getting misdiagnosed as a function of the symptoms they present with).

@ichudov Of course, but I was only using flu as an example, I meant I dont know why an after effect from Covid isn't called by the actual name of the medical issue concerned. In the sense that we don't say "long" anything else do we, only 'Long Covid'
@Mabel__Syrup__ @ichudov It was pricey, I remember that, LOL but  good
@BennsGirl @ichudov Yes...I believe that's the good stuff.
@ichudov I have 3 people in my close circle, all just had their booster, all have covid right now, yet here’s my family all unvaccinated, all still yet to catch any variant……Weird 🤨
